original_data.question: A 77-year-old man comes to your office for a routine visit. He is doing well, and his only complaint is the recent appearance of several brown greasy appearing lesions on his forehead (figure A) that he can't seem to peel off. What is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
This patient's lesions are most consistent with seborrheic keratosis. These are benign growths that can appear at any age but are more common in older individuals. They are usually multiple, vary in size, and can be peaked or flat. They are usually stuck on the skin and can be removed by a curette or by light cryotherapy. The other lesions listed are not stuck on the skin and are usually solitary.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

Shedding of the outer layer of skin or mucosal tissue.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
